headers.toc: Addition and Scalar Multiplication of Vectors

intro.para: Vectors can be added and they can be multiplied by a number. Vector addition corresponds to concatenating representing arrows, and multiplying a vector by a number corresponds to rescaling the length of a representing arrow. In this section we introduce both of these operations, how to compute effectively with these operations, and how to apply these operations in practical problems.

When we multiply a vector \Vect{x} by a number (a scalar) t, we keep the direction of \Vect{x} and multiply its length by t. The reason for this is the law of similar triangles:
